Shaanxi Key Laboratory of Energy Chemical Process Intensification School of Chemical Engineering and Technology Xi'an Jiaotong University Xi'an Shaanxi 710049 China Supported bimetallic catalysts have been paid great attention regarding their excellent catalytic performances in chemical process. Notably, comparing to monometallic catalysts, the synergetic properties of dual-metal-based materials demonstrate unique physiochemical functionalities that single metal materials do not possess. The preparation of supported bimetallic materials is widely conducted with applying the impregnation method because of the straightforward and inexpensive technique. Wherein, the impregnation of dual metals on support could either undergo co-impregnation or sequential impregnations. It has been frequently reported that there are substantial differences in physiochemical properties and catalyst performances by impregnation sequences. Specifically, during the investigation of various sequential impregnated bimetallic catalysts, a host of characterization strategies are employed to compare the physical and chemical properties that play vital role to impact the catalyst activity/selectivity/stability. However, it is still not well understood regarding the impregnation sequential effects, such as the nature of bimetallic active sites and the dynamics of bimetallic surface structures along with reaction progress. This presenting perspective article is devoted to take a succinct review regarding the general sequential impacts on the physiochemical properties and further profoundly address the research outlook in this topic. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract . Keywords Impregnation Supported bimetallic catalysts Co-impregnation Sequential impregnations Sequential effects Physiochemical properties 1 Introduction In heterogeneous catalysis, due to the synergetic functions of dual metals rather than single metal and the purpose of less precious metal utilizations, bimetallic catalysts have been largely studied and applied by leveraging their enhanced catalytic performances on activity/selectivity/stability toward chemical reactions. Commonly, these types of bimetallic catalysts might be supported on various types of supports, such as γ-Al2O3, SnO2, ZSM-5, SiO2, MgO, etc, with either acidic, basic or amphoteric functions [1]. Although a large set of additional methods for the preparation of supported metal catalysts, such as colloidal synthesis, deposition precipitation, strong electrostatic adsorption, are focused underway to advance their applications [2], impregnation approach is still one of the most practical methods that are broadly utilized in either chemical industry or academia because of the simpler and less expensive preparation process. Specifically, during impregnations of dual metals on support, there are typically two ways, one is co-impregnation of both metals while another one means the impregnation of each metal in sequence [2,3]. In this regard, it becomes significantly beneficial and promising to delve into the catalyst comparison of various impregnation sequences for more efficient bimetallic catalyst preparation. By far, a host of characterization tools (including physi-/chemisorption, temperature programmed techniques, spectroscopies, microcopies, etc.) have been developed are available to study the physical and chemical properties upon the metal-metal and metal-support interactions by impregnation sequential effects; additionally, the conversion/selectivity and stability of catalytic reactions are also commonly compared to study the catalyst performance in the related studies [3–8]. However, the realistic active sites and reaction kinetics on sequential impacted bimetallic materials remains less well explored, where it would be quite crucial to understand the inherent functionalities of bimetallic active sites in actual reaction environment and the structure dynamic phenomenon during reaction progress. Such investigations on the nature of active sites may further make the vital advisement to design and prepare more superior bimetallic catalysts with higher efficiency and less expense via the corresponding optimal impregnation sequence or other synthesis approaches that can be applied suitably. As of our best knowledge, no such impregnation sequential effects related perspective or (mini)review article has been available yet. Hence, this perspective article strives to take a concise tour to demonstrate the importance of impregnation sequential effected physiochemical properties of bimetallic catalysts by evaluating the recent representative literatures and raise the viewpoints to illustrate the imperative requirements to identify the realistic functionality of catalyst active sites and study the fundamental reaction kinetics impacted by the bimetallic impregnation sequences. Moreover, the comparison of catalyst structural dynamics from different sequences is also prospected to conduct thoroughly. 2 Impregnation methods for supported bimetallic catalysts Normally, one bimetallic catalyst consists of two different metals. To prepare the supported dual-metal catalyst, the respective metal salt solutions are expected to be impregnated onto the desired support. In this regard, the preparations of two metals could be conducted via either co-impregnation (the metal salts are impregnated simultaneously) or sequential impregnations (the metal salts are impregnated by orders). Specially, in the course of sequential impregnations, the order of adding two metal salts onto support could be reasonably switched. After the impregnations, the prepared materials are then dried, and calcined or reduced as needed to clean off precursor ligands and reduce the metal particles to zero-valent charge [2,9,10]. Thus, there are totally three kinds of impregnation processes for the preparation of supported bimetallic catalysts, shown in Fig. 1 (A). Herein, to indicate the various bimetallic catalysts more clearly, we denote the prepared catalysts via co-impregnation as A-B/S, where A and B are the two metals and S is the support; A/B/S presents the sequential impregnation with metal B first and metal A secondly; the B/A/S displays the sequential impregnation with metal A first and metal B after. Experimentally, There have been large amount of bimetallic catalysts prepared by impregnation via either sequential procedure or simultaneous operation, such as the Co based catalysts [5,11–18], Ni based catalysts [12,13,19–25], Pt based catalysts [20,22,26–28], etc. 3 Characterizations of impregnation sequential effects The study of physiochemical properties is the central part to acquire the elementary knowledge toward material functionalities. Similar as the monometallic catalysts, the investigations of physiochemical properties of supported bimetallic catalysts are extensively conducted through the profound insights on the textural properties (specific surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter), particle distribution (or crystallite distribution) and metallic state, metallic reducibility and activity, and catalyst acidity and basicity. In this section, we aim to take the opportunity to briefly walk through the fundamental comparison among different bimetallic impregnation sequences and discuss the associated effects in catalyst characterizations by reviewing the representative literatures. 3.1 Textural properties The exploration of textural properties mainly refers to the three principal physical qualities: specific surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter (or pore size). Commonly, catalyst support that possesses certain amount of specific surface area and pore volume to provide the accessible space for the impregnation of active metals and further facilitate the capability of molecule-surface allocation for catalytic reactions. Thus, it is always worth benchmarking the quantities of specific surface areas with the pure supports and the impregnated metallic catalysts. Importantly, it has shown that the specific surface area and pore volume of impregnated metallic (monometallic or bimetallic) catalysts are usually less than that in the clean support and the average pore size might be larger than that in pure support because of the metal particle depositions on the surface of support and the blockage of small pores [4,7,13,29,30]. However, due to the variable morphologies of surface particles by different impregnation sequences, it is not quite necessary to reach a universal consensus for an exclusive ranking order on the textural properties among the proposed impregnation sequences, A-B/S, A/B/S and B/A/S. Jing et al. reported that Ni/Co/MgO (Co is impregnated and Ni after) owns the highest specific surface area and lowest pore volume among the different impregnation sequences with Ni and Co on MgO, exhibited in Table 1 [12]; similarly, Phan et al. measured that the hydroxyapatite (HAP) supported catalyst with Co impregnated prior to Ni possesses the higher specific surface area than other sequential impregnated CoNi catalysts [31]. Whereas, Zhao et al. found that the specific surface area of Ni/Co/γ-Al2O3 (Co is impregnated and Ni after) is the lowest and there is no substantial change on pore volume among the various impregnation sequences with respect to Ni and Co on Al2O3 [12,13]. Noteworthily, excluding the unlikely influences from metal salts and impregnation solvents that are used the same in both MgO and Al2O3 supported bimetallic catalysts, the textural upshots could indicate that the catalyst supports might make their contributions into the bimetallic impregnations as well. In addition, the average pore diameters could be listed following the increasing order as Ni/Co/MgO < Co/Ni/MgO < NiCo/MgO, similarly, the ranking of Al2O3 supported catalysts displays as Co/Ni/Al2O3 < Ni/Co/Al2O3 < NiCo/Al2O3 with improving the average pore diameter [12,13]. Remarkably, it presents that the co-impregnated catalysts on both supports have highest average pore size, but the situation might change upon different metals or even different supports. For example, despite of the narrow range of average pore diameters among various impregnated materials, Sun et al. described that the average pore diameters of Cu and Fe contained dual metallic catalysts follow the rising trend as Cu-Fe/SiO2 < Cu/Fe/SiO2 < Fe/Cu/SiO2 [32]. Furthermore, together with the tendency of the MgO supported NiCo catalysts (as Table 1), Whelan et al. also measured the sequential impregnated carbon nanotube (CNT) supported CoMo catalysts follow with the improvement of specific surface area and the average pore diameter decline [11]. Such findings could demonstrate that the small size support pores are typically congested with the impregnated bimetallic particles [11]. Nevertheless, similar with the trends that the specific surface area increases when the average pore diameter grows for the Ni and Co based catalysts reported by Zhao et al., Osakoo et al. reported the substantial difference on textural results between the sequential impregnated PdCo/SBA-15 material and the co-impregnated one quantitatively, where the sequential impregnated PdCo owns higher pore volume (0.95 cm3/g) than the co-impregnated one (0.85 cm3/g) and the specific surface area of the sequential impregnated PdCo catalyst (473 m2/g) is also much larger than the bimetallic material prepared via co-impregnation (397 m2/g) [33]. 3.2 Particle distribution and metallic state Metallic particle size (or crystallite size) and dispersion are the two key factors that can significantly lead to the catalyst performances because the exposed active sites on metals are supposed to be directly impacted by the values of particle size and dispersion. Thus, it will be beneficial to impregnate two kinds of metals suitably by leveraging the metal-metal or metal-support interaction to elevate the metallic dispersion so that the particle size shrinks with appreciable amount [7]. Particle size and metal dispersion, which can be essentially impacted by the impregnation sequence, are usually quantified by the X-ray diffraction (XRD) [11,12,21,27,34], transmission electron microscopy (TEM) [12,13,16,19,20,33], H2-/CO-chemisorption [13,35]. In addition, the surface identification and compositions of sequential impregnated bimetallic catalysts can also be investigated with using the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) [13,19,22,25], Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) or diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) [18,32], Raman spectroscopy [11], X-ray absorption spectroscopy structure (XAS) [20,28], inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) [19], etc. Typically, low crystallite size could suggest the higher metal dispersion [13,33]. For the silica supported bimetallic catalysts involving Cu and Fe after calcination, the XRD results revealed that there are crystal CuO and α-Fe2O3 in the catalyst samples [32]. Specifically, according to the crystallite sizes, Cu/Fe/SiO2 was found to include both the largest crystal of CuO and α-Fe2O3; whereas, Cu-Fe/SiO2 and Fe/Cu/SiO2 contain the smallest crystallite size on CuO and α-Fe2O3, respectively. Moreover, the analogous tendencies were observed on the reduced catalysts regarding the crystal Cu and Fe3O4 [32], as exhibited in Fig. 1(B). In addition, to confirm the surface contents of Cu and Fe in both of the calcined and reduced catalysts, XPS, H2-TPR and DRIFT were also employed to study the catalyst surface properties [32]. Next, for Cu based bimetallic catalysts, Naicker et al. carried out the comparison of bimetallic (CuAg) dispersions on the support, γ-Al2O3, among multiple alternative impregnations through the carbon monoxide chemisorption. Considerably, the distinctions were measured that the catalyst S-0.5Ag-4.5Cu/γ-Al2O3 (Ag is impregnated first and Cu after) has the highest metal dispersion, but the lowest value is observed on the catalyst S-4.5Cu-0.5Ag/γ-Al2O3 (Cu is impregnated first and Ag after). The dispersion of the co-impregnated one (4.5Cu-0.5Ag/γ-Al2O3) is slightly smaller than that on S-0.5Ag-4.5Cu/γ-Al2O3 [4]. These outcomes could suggest that the Cu metal surface area is essentially depressed by the deposition of Ag when Cu is impregnated first and Ag afterward [4]. TEM is a very common and powerful characterization tool to acquire the fundamental understanding of surface morphology and particle distribution of bimetallic catalysts. By leveraging TEM-EDX (energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy), Di et al. conducted a comprehensive study toward the sequential impacts together with various metal loadings regarding the impregnated Co-Re/TiO2 catalyst system [14]. As shown in Fig. 2 (a), it presents the TEM-EDX results for all the catalyst samples, including the sequential prepared materials with Co impregnated first and Re afterword, labeled as SI-4Co-1Re/TiO2 and SI-4Co-5Re/TiO2 with different weight loadings; the co-impregnated catalyst, CI-4Co-1Re/TiO2. At first, they measured that the mean particle diameters are 0.8 nm and 25 nm for Co/TiO2 and Re/TiO2, respectively [14]. Meanwhile, they only had a chance to observe the lattice spacing of the sample Re/TiO2 (with smaller particle size) with 2.10 Å. In the similar way, the corresponding analogous lattice spacing values of Co(111), Co(101) and Re(101) on the sequential impregnated bimetallic catalysts SI-4Co-1Re/TiO2 and SI-4Co-5Re/TiO2 are exhibited in Fig. 2(a) [14]. It was concluded that the lattice spacing changes between the sequential impregnated catalysts and the Re/TiO2 can be attributed to the metal interaction of Co and Re, and the effect of catalyst support as well. The EDX results confirm that the bimetallic catalyst Co-Re is well prepared with a surface structure of Janus-type, presented in Fig. 2(b)-(B) [14]. Furthermore, according to the particle distributions shown in Fig. 2(b)-(A), it indicates that the average particle size of Re increases with improving the Re loading but the average particle size of Co decreases when the Re loading is promoted [14], which could suggest that the first-impregnated Co particles might assist the reduction of Re salt precursor and further interact with Re nearby. In the meantime, the Re particles may enhance the higher dispersion of Co on the support surface [14]. Lastly, as shown in Fig. 2(a), it finds that the isolated Co and Re particles (depicted as Fig. 2(b)-(B)) are formed during the co-impregnation of CI-4Co-1Re/TiO2 catalyst and the Co particle sizes are similar in CI-4Co-1Re/TiO2 and Co/TiO2. Interestingly, no Re is markedly observed in the TEM might manifest that the Re is dispersed well. In this respect, it is pronounced that the metal-metal interaction (here as Co-Re interaction) is generated through the sequential impregnation manner rather than co-impregnation [14]. Furthermore, although it is quite challenging to purposefully prepare one desired catalyst surface structure with using impregnation method, intriguingly, it has been reported that the co-impregnated NiZr catalyst presents a core-shell structure, where NiO is deposited inside the ZrO2 nanoparticles. Whereas the NiO nanoparticles are observed to be located nearby ZrO2 and also on the support surface for the sequential impregnated NiZr sample [23]. On the other hand, the vital difference between sequential impregnated and co-impregnated bimetallic materials can be from the localization of nanoparticles on support surface [33]. Meaningfully, the SBA-15 supported PdCo samples prepared with various sequences of impregnation were studied regarding the particle positions with using TEM-EDX before and after the catalytic reaction [33]. The fresh calcined SBA-15 supported PdCo catalysts were reported that the metal oxides in the sequential impregnated catalyst are substantially dispersed inside the support channel (presented in Fig. 3 (a)-(B)) and the particles in the co-impregnated one are deposited on both the inside the support channel and the external surface (presented in Fig. 3(a)-(A)) [33]. After the use of reaction, the catalyst particles from the sequential impregnation and co-impregnation can be observed on either external surface or the cavities of the support [33]. In this regard, for the thorough comparison of the sequential impregnations, it soundly emphasizes the importance to benchmark the surface properties between the fresh and used bimetallic materials. Besides, not only via TEM, it has been also reported that the scanning electron microscopy and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (SEM-EDX) was applied to compare the particle dispersions and surface homogeneities with respect to the various sequential impregnated CePt/ZrO2 catalysts [26]. Moreover, the metal element states in bimetallic catalysts have been analyzed by XAS to compare the various sequential impregnated materials [19,20]. For instance, Kim et al. conducted the study of X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) on the carbon supported NiPd catalysts toward the dehydrogenation of formic acid. As shown in Fig. 3(b), the 6 catalyst samples, including those prepared via sequential impregnation and the monometal Pd, were tested by XAS [19]. It is quite clear that the various samples indeed present different profiles with respect to the corresponding state of Pd particles. Specifically, the co-impregnated NiPd catalyst (label as Pd1NiO1.3/C(co)) and the monometal Pd/C follow the analogues trend with the Pd metal [19]. However, the Pd states in the sequential impregnated samples are more similar with the Pd(OH)2 or PdO. Besides, it is not hard to observe that the molar ratio of Ni to Pd could be another factor to impact the Pd state in the bimetallic materials [19]. Upon these findings, the authors also addressed that the extent of oxidized Pd has directly exhibited the catalytic performance [19]. As of another essential analysis approach from XAS, the Pt LIII-edge Extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) was applied to confirm the metal-metal interaction of the γ-Al2O3 supported NiPt catalysts with sequential effect by Shu et al. [20]. During the study, the interaction Pt-Ni and Pt-Pt were majorly detected. The Pt-Ni interaction was carefully measured in both the 1Ni-1Pt/γ-Al2O3 (impregnation of Pt first and Ni after) and 1Pt-1Ni/γ-Al2O3 (impregnation of Ni first and Pt after) catalysts, where the two samples have the equivalent Pt:Ni molar ratio but follow the opposite sequences of impregnation [20]. Interestingly, there is no such Pt-Ni bond observed in the sample 1Pt-1/3Ni/γ-Al2O3 (impregnation of Ni first and Pt after, Ni:Pt is 3), alternatively, they measured a small coordination of Pt–Ni in the 1/3Ni-1Pt/γ-Al2O3 (impregnation of Ni first and Pt after, Ni:Pt is 1/3) catalyst [20]. 3.3 Metallic reducibility and activity Hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) is typically applied in the reducibility study of bimetallic catalysts [17,28]. From such experimental results, temperature shift and size change of the reduction peaks from stronger oxidized state to less oxidized state or zero charge valent might suggest the differences of crystallite structures and the reducibility of bimetallic materials with different impregnation sequences. Wherein, the impregnation sequential influences on metal-metal or metal-support interaction and catalytic activity could be revealed through the TPR experiment purposefully [4,5,17,21,28,34]. Pedersen et al. conducted a set of H2-TPR experiments on the Al2O3 supported CoMn materials [5]. As shown in Fig. 4 (Left), there are majorly two distinctive peaks demonstrating the Co3O4 reduction, 290 to 330 °C and 410 to 550 °C. Comparing with the reduction profile of Co and Mn, it is not difficult to find out that the displayed peaks among the Co → Mn (Co is impregnated first and Mn after) sample, Co sample and Mn sample are analogous but the catalyst Co → Mn owns the elevated intensity and reduction temperature for the first peak (the reduction of Co3O4). Besides, no vital change on the second reduction peak (the Mn reduction) were observed among these three samples [5]. The reduction profile of Mn → Co sample (Mn is impregnated first and Co after) presents alike reduction peaks with the reference Co reduction, which is able to express that the reduction of Mn is poor [5]. However, for the catalyst Co + Mn (Co and Mn are co-impregnated) specially, the reduction temperature of the second essential reduction peak (the referred peaks from 410 to 550 °C) shifts up and meanwhile the peak presents much wider than the referred peaks in other samples [5]. This finding has been illustrated frequently that the higher temperature and wider reduction peak on Co + Mn sample could be ascribed to the formation of the metal-metal interacted crystallite structure, Co3-xMnxO4 [5,36,37]. Nevertheless, either different bimetallic combinations or supports could play their essential roles as well. In addition, for another set of Co based bimetallic catalysts, the co-impregnated catalyst CoMo was found to possess the lowest reduction temperature [11]. Besides, the γ-Al2O3 supported AuNi catalyst with various methods of preparation were investigated regarding their significant distinctions on the particle structure and metallic state [21]. As exhibited in Fig. 4(Middle), the impregnated monometal catalysts, Ni/γ-Al2O3(C) and Au/γ-Al2O3(C); the sequential impregnated bimetallic catalyst, Au-Ni(SI)/γ-Al2O3(C) (Ni is impregnated first); the co-impregnated sample, Au-Ni(CI)/γ-Al2O3(C); the catalyst prepared by deposition–precipitation method, Au-Ni(DP)/γ-Al2O3(C) are together compared in one window. The authors mentioned that there is no available peak observed on the Au catalyst but only slight increase of baseline on the Ni sample. Such findings indicate that the Au particles had been fully reduced to zero charge after the calcination of Au/γ-Al2O3(C) and portion of NiO particles exist in the Ni/γ-Al2O3(C) sample [21]. More importantly, it is explicit to observe that the largest reduction peak at 260 °C and the subsequent peak at 410 °C occur in the Au-Ni(CI)/γ-Al2O3(C) catalyst. Especially, the second (or the higher temperature) peak could manifest that there is the strong metal-metal (here as Au-Ni) interaction [21,38,39]. In addition, a considerable peak at 210 °C shows up in the Au-Ni(SI)/γ-Al2O3(C) sample; however, the peak intensity is relatively lower. In this respect, it proposes that the highest activity can be acquired on the co-impregnated catalyst. The Au-Ni(DP)/γ-Al2O3(C) sample presents a wide reduction peak after 400 °C [21]. To further emphasize the impregnation sequential effect on the catalyst reducibility, despite the bimetallic catalysts are the central materials to be discussed in this article, it is still quite worth presenting another brief case of understating the sequential impregnated trimetallic catalysts with using H2-TPR [34]. Analogously, a host of silica supported trimetallic catalysts, including Rh-Fe-Ce/SiO2 (simultaneously impregnated for Rh, Fe and Ce), Ce/Rh-Fe/SiO2 (Rh and Fe are together impregnated first, Ce afterward), Rh-Fe/Ce/SiO2 (Ce is impregnated first, Rh and Fe are together impregnated secondly), and Rh-Fe/SiO2 (Rh and Fe are co-impregnated), were prepared to study the impacts from sequential impregnation. As shown in Fig. 4(Right), there are totally three types of reduction peaks (labeled as α, β and γ in the figure) observed in the four samples. Specially, the bulk Ce4+ reduction peak, γ peak, only exists in the Ce/Rh-Fe and Rh-Fe/Ce catalysts [34,40]. Quantitatively, the H2-TPR outcomes demonstrate that the Rh-Fe-Ce sample owns the largest amount of consumed H2, the total peak area of α and β peaks, namely. The consumed H2 in the Rh-Fe/Ce catalyst is the smallest among three trimetallic catalysts [34]. According to the reduction temperature of the first two dominating peaks, it has revealed that the metal-metal interaction in the Rh-Fe-Ce catalyst is the strongest, and such interaction in the Rh-Fe/Ce sample is relatively weaker. Moreover, it proposed that the α and β peaks could be referred to the reduction of Rh2O3 or the Ce4+ adjacent Rh particles [34,41]. According to the catalyst-adsorbate interaction, such as between H2 or CO and active metals, in general, the H2/CO-chemisorption or H2/CO-TPD can be appropriately utilized to conduct the accounting of metallic active sites for the quantitative comparison of sequential impact [27,33,35]. Despite of the structure complexity and surface dynamics in the bimetallic catalysts, it is still acceptable to quantify the uptake of H2 or CO to evaluate the number of active sites on bimetallic samples prepared by different impregnation sequences. Zhang et al. studied the H2-chemisorption of the K/ZSM-5 supported Pt and Sn metallic materials with PtSn (Co-impregnated), Pt-Sn (Pt is impregnated first) and Sn-Pt (Sn is impregnated first) at various temperatures (30 °C, 300 °C and 450 °C) [27]. They observed that the increasing order of total H2 uptake could be arranged as Sn-Pt < Pt-Sn < PtSn, which might indicate that the number of active sites on PtSn is the largest and Sn-Pt has lowest site density. Moreover, the findings also specified that the H2 uptake occurs at multiple temperatures and improves as temperature climbs up on the co-impregnated PtSn sample [27]. Combining with prior studies [42], researchers concluded that the higher uptake could be attributed to the strong Pt-SnOx interaction in the PtSn catalyst. Meantime, the comparison of uptake tendency between Sn-Pt and Pt-Sn along with temperature suggests that the capability of the Pt-SnOx interaction might be altered by the impregnation sequences that further impacted the structures of the bimetallic nanoparticles [27]. Specifically, at low temperature (30 °C), the consumed H2 amounts were measured as 4.4 ml g−1, 6.6 ml g−1 and 5.8 ml g−1 on PtSn, Sn-Pt and Pt-Sn, respectively; however, they became 9.7 ml g−1, 7.0 ml g−1 and 8.8 ml g−1 correspondingly on the three samples at 450 °C and such trend was measured at 300 °C as well. In other words, the H2 uptake of Sn-Pt catalyst is the highest comparing with the other two at 30 °C but it is the lowest at 450 °C and 300 °C. The researchers reported that such observation on Sn-Pt could be ascribed to the two types of Pt active sites, where one type is from the substantial amount of Pt particles deposited on the support that is responsible for the H2 uptake at the low temperature, but another one could come from the less amount of formed Pt-SnOx in charge of the high-temperature uptake of H2 [27,42]. To enhance the understanding of sequential effects on the Al2O3 supported FeRhMn catalyst quantitively and quantitively, a series of chemisorption and TPD techniques were employed to mainly compare the three different catalysts, Fe-RhMn/Al2O3 (Fe is impregnated, Rh and Mn are co-impregnated after), RhMn–Fe/Al2O3 (Rh and Mn are co-impregnated and Fe afterward) and RhMnFe/Al2O3 (Rh, Mn and Fe are impregnated simultaneously) [35]. In this regard, although there are three metals in the prepared materials, the preparation approach still follows with the “two-batch” impregnation in sequence. In the CO-chemisorption experiment, the results demonstrate that there are indeed considerably differences of CO site count and metal dispersion for the tested samples. In detail, the catalyst Fe-RhMn/Al2O3 is quantified with the highest amount of the chemisorbed CO (58.9 μmol g−1) and the corresponding dispersion of metallic particles (57.2%); whereas, the co-impregnated catalyst RhMnFe/Al2O3 exhibits the lowest CO consumption (34.1 μmol g−1) and metallic dispersion (33.5%), shown in Table 2 [35]. Moreover, the authors conducted CO-TPD experiment to benchmark the surface configurations of those impregnated catalysts. As presented in Fig. 5(A) , three major desorption peaks show up on each sample. Except the indicated two different desorption temperatures for every single profile in the figure, one more peak around the temperature range between 80 and 200 °C was mentioned in the literature as well. Wherein, it is worth noting that both the desorption peak temperature and peak area could suggest that extent of the adsorption strength on catalyst [35,43]. More specifically, the Fe–RhMn/Al2O3 sample does not only exhibit the highest desorption peak (denoted as the peak at 598 °C in Fig. 5(A)) but also possess the largest area of the related peak. Combining the trends obtained from CO-chemisorption, the sequential impregnated catalyst Fe–RhMn/Al2O3 is thought to be the efficient catalyst to adsorb and further activate CO [35]. On the other hand, by leveraging the H2-TPD, the activation capabilities of the three sequential impregnated catalysts to molecular hydrogen were evaluated and the outcomes demonstrated that the RhMn–Fe/Al2O3 sample is the better candidate to proceed the catalytic hydrogenation [35]. 3.4 Catalyst acidity and basicity According to the chemical roles of metals and supports, supported metallic catalysts may not only offer the capability for reductive or oxidative chemistry but also possess acidity and basicity for proton or electron transfer reaction [44,45]. Wherein, there are fair chances that impregnation sequence makes substantial influences into the acid-base property of supported bimetallic materials. To this end, the temperature programmed desorption (TPD) technique and FT-IR could be broadly employed to systematically compare the acidity and basicity of various sequential impregnated catalysts. More specifically, NH3-/alkylamines-/pyridine-TPD and the corresponding FT-IR are the common approaches for both the qualification and quantification of catalyst acidities (including Brønsted/Lewis acidity) and additionally CO2-TPD is an appropriate manner to examine the number of basic sites [4,15,22,24,25,46]. Typically, upon the temperature of desorption peaks showing up, the acidity or basicity with weak, moderate, or strong mode is expected to be accounted into the total acid density of bimetallic catalysts. For instance, the comparison of acid sites on the γ-Al2O3 supported CuAg by various impregnation sequences was investigated with employing NH3-TPD [4]. As shown in Table 3 , among the three bimetallic catalysts by different impregnation, it reveals that both the co-impregnated sample (4.5Cu-0.5Ag/γ-Al2O3) and sequential impregnated sample (S-4.5Cu-0.5Ag/γ-Al2O3) have similar higher values of total acid density than the sequential impregnated sample (S-0.5Ag-4.5Cu/γ-Al2O3) [4]. In addition, the strong acidic sites on the co-impregnated catalyst are much higher than that on S-4.5Cu-0.5Ag/γ-Al2O3, which might be ascribed to the number of calcination cycle performed on both catalysts [4]. By far, it is not strange that impregnation sequential impacts exist on the catalyst acidity; whereas it is not trivial to precisely differentiate the types (either Brønsted or Lewis) of acid sites with only applying the NH3 titration on TPD [4,15,24,46]. Besides of the titration of total acidity on catalyst surface, it would be essentially beneficial to conduct the NH3 or pyridine based FT-IR experiment for the identification of acidic types. Nugrahaningtyas et al. reported that there are considerable differences on the acidities among the Ultra Stable Y-zeolite (USY) supported CoMo catalysts with sequential or co-impregnation [15]. From Fig. 5(B), the three NH3-FT-IR spectroscopies for all the prepared catalysts, including Co_Mo/USY sample is (Co is impregnated first and Mo after), Mo_Co/USY (Mo is impregnated prior to Co), CoMo/USY (co-impregnation of Co and Mo), are clearly labeled. First of all, the researchers resolved that the Mo_Co/USY catalyst is the most stable sample because of its pronounced Al-O-metal interaction represented by the lower vibrational shift between the wavenumber 3000 and 3750 cm−1 [15]. Next, it shows that all of the USY supported catalysts have the comparable amounts of Brønsted acid site denoted by the NH3 adsorption peak at the wavenumber 1600 cm−1 approximately; however, only the sequential impregnated Mo_Co/USY catalyst presents substantial quantity of Lewis acid sites referred by the adsorption band at 1500 cm−1 approximately, and there is no available Lewis acid site observed in the co-impregnated sample, CoMo/USY [15]. Overall, it suggested that the highest total acidity is acquired in the sequential impregnated sample, Mo_Co/USY [15]. Another most often utilized molecule for the surface titration of acid sites is pyridine, which could be tested with the techniques either by TPD or FT-IR. Thus, it is reasonable that such pyridine-based titration experiments are accessible to evaluate the sequential impregnated bimetallic catalysts with respect to the inherent acidity [22,25]. Betti et al. have investigated the sequential effects on the γ-Al2O3 supported Pt-Ni catalyst system [22]. From Table 4 , the sequential impregnated are denoted as NiNPt (NiN is impregnated prior to Pt), NiClPt (NiCl is impregnated prior to Pt), PtNiCl (Pt is impregnated prior to NiCl2) and PtNiN (Pt is impregnated prior to Ni(NO3)2). Based on the three different strengths of acid site shown in Table 4, it explicitly demonstrates that the catalysts with Pt first impregnated, namely PtNiCl and PtNiN, possess higher amount of total acid sites. More detailly, among the four bimetallic catalysts, the total acid density is measured with the highest in NiClPt, whereas the lowest one is obtained in PtNiN. In the meantime, it is also important to point out that not only the impregnation sequential impact exists, but the metal salt precursors also play their roles to the physiochemical parameters of the bimetallic catalysts [22]. Specially, the researchers proved that the TPD findings are also supported by the related XPS study and further addressed that the Cl species in NiClPt would be another game changer besides of impregnation sequence to provide the sizeable total acid density comparing with the other bimetallic samples [22,47]. Lastly, the pyridine-TPD results have also manifested that the total amount of acid sites in each bimetallic catalyst is far larger than that in the supported Ni catalyst [22]. On the other hand, Guo et al. reported the comparison of various sequential impregnated Ni-W/MCM-41 catalysts with applying the pyridine-FT-IR [25]. They basically prepared four various samples based on impregnation sequence (sequential and co-impregnation) and catalyst drying condition (drying under air and vacuum). Qualitatively, the Brønsted acid and Lewis acid were explicitly differentiated by identifying the wavenumbers of corresponding FT-IR bands, where the researchers found that the number of Lewis acid sites is more than the Brønsted acid sites [25]. Quantitatively, the Ni-W sample prepared by co-impregnated sample and vacuum drying method presented the highest acid density; whereas the lowest acid density was measured in the sequential impregnated Ni-W catalyst (W impregnated prior to Ni and dried by air). At this point, they concluded that both simultaneous impregnation and vacuum condition might be better option boost the acid density [25]. Next, it is greatly valuable to accurately measure the catalyst basicity that could be responsible to certain types of reactions, such as methane dry reforming. First of all, it is worth noting that typically the basic site with weak peak, strong peak or medium peak could be reflected out during the CO2-TPD experiment [24,48,49]. Arbag carried out the comparison study of impregnation sequence impacts toward basicity of the mesoporous alumina supported MgNi dual metal catalysts with using CO2-TPD [24]. The experiment found that the TPD profiles (exhibited in Fig. 6 (A)) of the bimetallic catalysts impregnated with Mg (denoted as Mg-Ni@, Ni@Mg@ and Mg@Ni@) are quite distinctive with the profiles on the Ni catalyst (labeled as Ni@) and the mesoporous alumina support (labeled as MA) regarding the desorption temperatures and the corresponding peak areas, especially on the two samples, Mg-Ni@ and Ni@Mg@ [24]. Interestingly, combining with the previous study [50], the researchers confirmed that the functionality of Mg species and Ni species are converse, where the former could increase the basic site on the alumina support but the latter would decrease the basicity of the alumina support, shown in Fig. 6(A) [24]. Besides, similarly toward the catalyst application in dry reforming reaction of methane, Sun et al. investigated the trimetallic catalyst system Co-Ce-M/AC-N (AC-N stands for N-doped activated carbon) with the preparation methods in various impregnation orders, where the M was denoted by either Mg or Ca [16]. Despite three metals were employed to prepare the catalysts, the concept of sequential impregnation is analogous with the bimetallic impregnation. According to Fig. 6(B), there are totally four different CO2 desorption peaks (as labeled by dashed line in the figure) showing up along with increasing the programmed temperature. Correspondingly, the strengths of basic site are weak at low temperature peak about 150 °C, moderate at the desorption temperature around 450 °C and strong for the temperature above 550 °C but until 850 °C. Remarkedly, for the Ca impregnation sequential influence, all the Ca promoted catalysts (including 1Co-1Ce-1Ca/AC-N, 1Co-1Ce-/1Ca/AC-N and 1Ca/1Co-1Ce/AC-N) present larger desorbed peak areas of the strong basic sites, meanwhile, the temperatures of these desorption peaks shift to the right side in the various extents, accordingly. In practical, such substantial improvement of basicity was proposed to be beneficial for the activation of CO2 during methane dry reforming and enhancement of catalytic stability. Moreover, based on the comparison of the desorption peaks at about 150 and 450 °C, it revealed that the Ca promoted catalysts could elevate the CO2 weakly adsorbed basic sites but decrease the moderate basic sites comparing with the non-promoted sample, 1Co-1Ce/AC-N [16]. From above, it has shown the representative cases of CO2-TPD toward the understanding of sequential effects on supported bimetallic catalysts that are used for the dry reforming of methane. In addition, the basic site of metallic catalysts could be also applied to the CO2 hydrogenation system, where the adsorption and activation of small molecule CO2 is required on the catalyst surface [23]. In this regard, bimetallic materials might possess the synergistic functionality with metal-metal or metal-support interaction to improve the catalytic process more efficiently during the hydrogenation of CO2. Thus, it becomes necessary and urgent to discover the sequential impacts for the design and preparation of promising catalyst. Romero-Sáez et al. conducted the CO2-TPD experiments to study the quantity and strength of the basic sites on the bimetallic NiZr catalyst supported by CNT [23]. As presented in Fig. 6(C), the three different types of surface basic sites are labeled by α, β, and γ for weak, medium, and strong strength, respectively. Essentially, all the three kinds of basic strengths show up on both the sequential impregnated catalyst, Ni/Zr/CNT-SEQ, and the co-impregnated sample, Ni/Zr/CNT-COI. In detail, the weak site, medium site and strong site of basicity are attributed to the hydroxyl group associated with ZrO2, the Zr-O interaction and the O atoms in low coordination, respectively [23,51–53]. As proposed by the authors, it is worth noting that there might be essential ZrO2-CNT interactions being responsible to the observed multiple medium sites of basicity on those bimetallic samples [23,54]. Quantitatively, based on the calculated relative site density value in the parenthesis above each TPD profile in Fig. 6(C), the Ni/Zr/CNT-SEQ sample owns the highest total basic site density rather than the co-impregnated one. Although a desorption peak at low temperature suggesting the weak-basic site is observed on the monometallic Ni catalyst, it reveals that the number of this weak-basic site is lower than those weak-basic sites on the bimetallic catalysts [23]. 4 Perspectives and conclusions Upon the last section above, the general characterization strategies toward the fundamental understanding of impregnation sequential effects have been briefly discussed and evaluated. Essentially, to thoroughly study the metal-metal or metal-support interaction in supported bimetallic catalysts behind catalytic performances, we have visited the physicochemical properties, including textual properties, particle distribution and metallic state, metallic reducibility and activity, metallic acidity and basicity, during the comparison of impregnation sequences. Indeed, owing to the substantial differences in physiochemical properties and catalytic performances among various impregnation sequences, it indicates that such sequential effects cannot be ignored, instead, it needs to be significantly considered in the preparation of supported bimetallic catalysts. Besides, what is also noteworthy is that there are also quite a few of other factors together impacting the physical and chemical properties of supported bimetallic catalysts during preparation. These factor can consist of catalyst support [12,13], molar ratio of dual metals [7,14,19,55–57], pH value of impregnation solution [22], catalyst pretreatment condition [25], etc. Furthermore, despite the catalyst performance examinations (involving reaction conversion/selectivity and catalytic stability) have been frequently compared among different sequences of bimetallic impregnations in literatures [11,13,16,19,21,22,27,31], the nature of bimetallic active sites and related catalytic reaction kinetics from such impregnation sequential influences remains less understood. Hence, for the central purpose of designing and preparing efficient catalysts, more essential research is rather necessary for the systematic understanding of impregnation sequential effects. First of all, it can be the identification of bimetallic active sites that are realistically responsible to the improvement of catalyst efficiency but not only the quantification of active sites with using surface titration. Another point is the careful comparison of the preparation sequence regarding the reaction kinetics, e.g., intrinsic reaction rate, reaction barriers, deactivation rate (if applicable), but not just based on conversion/selectivity/stability. Thirdly, it would be much beneficial to broadly investigate the surface properties and kinetic parameters of bimetallic materials before and after treatments/reactions or observe the restructuring evolutions of catalyst surfaces during reactions realistically with employing other characterization manners, such as in situ/Operando spectroscopies and steady state isotopic transient kinetic analysis (SSITKA) [58–60]. Last but not the least, by leveraging the wide-ranging characterizations of physical and chemical properties from the sequential effects of bimetallic impregnations, the exploration of other catalytic materials, e.g., supported trimetallic catalysts [16,34,35,61], co-metal oxides catalysts [62], co-supported metal catalysts [63–66], could be effectively benefited. In addition, since bimetallic catalysts are generally prepared based on the similar manner of monometallic materials [10], the discoveries of sequential impacts on the impregnation method could potentially offer the abundant knowledge into other synthetic approaches, such as the charge enhanced dry impregnation [2,67,68], colloidal method [69]. To sum up, we have taken a concise evaluation on the impregnation sequential effects by leveraging the representative literatures and brought out the viewpoints toward the meaningful understanding of such sequence related impacts in the characterizations of supported bimetallic materials. To meet with the specific requirements of chemical reactions, the capabilities of sequential impregnation can be quite flexible with respect to different physiochemical properties of desired bimetallic catalysts. Macroscopically, the comprehensive understanding of impregnation sequential effects is imperative to the development of efficient and low-cost bimetallic catalysts either in the surface formats of nanoparticles or nanoclusters to facilitate the sustainable fuel and chemical productions. coredata.dc:description: Supported bimetallic catalysts have been paid great attention regarding their excellent catalytic performances in chemical process. Notably, comparing to monometallic catalysts, the synergetic properties of dual-metal-based materials demonstrate unique physiochemical functionalities that single metal materials do not possess. The preparation of supported bimetallic materials is widely conducted with applying the impregnation method because of the straightforward and inexpensive technique. Wherein, the impregnation of dual metals on support could either undergo co-impregnation or sequential impregnations. It has been frequently reported that there are substantial differences in physiochemical properties and catalyst performances by impregnation sequences. Specifically, during the investigation of various sequential impregnated bimetallic catalysts, a host of characterization strategies are employed to compare the physical and chemical properties that play vital role to impact the catalyst activity/selectivity/stability. However, it is still not well understood regarding the impregnation sequential effects, such as the nature of bimetallic active sites and the dynamics of bimetallic surface structures along with reaction progress. This presenting perspective article is devoted to take a succinct review regarding the general sequential impacts on the physiochemical properties and further profoundly address the research outlook in this topic.
coredata.dc:title: Characterizing the sequential effects toward the impregnations of supported bimetallic catalysts
